Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive explanation of the differences between umbrella swifts, skein winders, and how they are used for winding skeins vs. unwinding hanks:

## Key Differences Between Swifts and Skein Winders

There's a difference between a swift and a skein winder. Swifts are adjustable, for unwinding skeins of different lengths. Skein winders are fixed length (traditionally 2 yards) for creating skeins, often for consistent amounts of yarn.

### Umbrella Swift
- The most popular swift works much like the inner workings of an umbrella, hence its name, the umbrella swift. A center pole clamps onto a table. The pole holds several crisscrossed arms (usually between 5 and 8) that sit flush to the pole, like an umbrella. As you push up the pole from the bottom, the arms slowly extend outwards. The entire umbrella mechanism floats on the pole, so that it can spin freely as you unwind the skein and wind your ball.

- Keep in mind that the swift was designed for unraveling skeins rather than winding them.

- Umbrella Swifts are the easiest to store.

### Skein Winders
- Skein winders and click reels don't serve as umbrella swift replacements because they usually do not have a flexible circumference. They are intended to help you make hanks, not unravel them.

## How to Unwind Hanks Using a Swift

The purpose of a swift is to prevent yarn from tangling when you wind yarn into a ball. Swifts are mainly used to wind hanks of yarn into balls that unravel from the center.(no content)A hank of yarn is essentially one long piece of yarn looped together to form one big circle. The ring of yarn is twisted together to make a neat skein ready for packaging. Indie dyed or other higher end yarn will generally be packaged as a hank. You don't want to start knitting or crocheting off of a hank though.

**The process:**
1. Take your yarn hanks and remove any labels on it so that it's a circular loop. You'll place the hank of yarn over your yarn swift and expand the swift out until the skein is taut on it.

2. Don't untie the hank! Wait until the hank form is on the swift. If using an umbrella swift, put the yarn circle around the yarn swift. Open out the extendable sections. Push the center upwards until it fits snugly around the skein form.

3. Remove the yarn ties from the yarn. If using a yarn ball winder and swift, hold the yarn end from the outside. This ensures it doesn't interrupt the flow of the swift. Attach it to the ball winder, and place it through the yarn guide arm and on the bobbin.

4. The swift will rotate in a circle as the yarn unwinds and turns into a ball. The process is finished when no more yarn remains on the swift.

## Alternative Swift Types

Another popular type of swift is called the Amish swift or tabletop swift. The device sits on its base on top of the table or floor. The base is attached to a couple of thin wood pieces that criss-cross in the middle that form an "X" and create four arms. There is a connecting piece in the middle of the arms and base that allows the contraption to rotate. The four long arms have a series of holes that extend to the end. There are pegs that fit inside the holes. The pegs can be moved to different holes to accommodate the size of hank. The swift will rotate and unwind the yarn into a ball in the same way as an umbrella swift.

## Using a Swift for Winding (Not Just Unwinding)

While the umbrella swift is normally used after yarn has been skeined on a niddy noddy, some spinners prefer to wind their skeins directly from wheel to swift, skipping the niddy noddy entirely. If you want to try this, remember to measure the length of yarn that's used in one full rotation of the swift. Knowing this measurement lets you know how much yarn is in your skein by counting the strands in the skein and multiplying that number by the length of yarn in one rotation.(no content)A swift is best used in conjunction with a ball winder. The two work together to wind giant loops of yarn into compact center pull cakes in a matter of minutes.

Here are the search results for yarn ball winder and swift tutorials:

## Yarn Ball Winder and Swift Tutorials

I found several helpful tutorials on how to use a yarn ball winder and swift:

### What Are They?
- A yarn winder is used to wind yarn into a neat, center pull cake. A swift is used to hold the loose yarn and keep it from being tangled while you wind.

- A yarn ball winder is a tool that winds yarn into neat cakes, making it easier for knitting and crocheting. It saves a huge amount of time compared to winding yarn by hand.

### Why You Need Them
- Before you can knit with yarn that's in a skein, you have to wind it into a ball, otherwise, it will end up in a very tangled mess! There are two common ways to do this: by hand or with a swift and ball winder.

- Ball winders can quickly transform hanks of yarn into a center pull ball of yarn that is easy to knit from and won't tangle. If you're winding a center-pull skein into a ball, you don't need to use a yarn swift. If your yarn comes in a hank, though, you need to use the ball winder with a swift. Otherwise, the hank of yarn will become very tangled if you try to wind it directly.

### How to Set Up
1. All swifts are constructed similarly, with expandable arms that resemble an umbrella, and a stand or bracket at the bottom, which you secure to a tabletop. Secure the base of your swift to a sturdy table, and keep the arms loose for now. Then secure your ball winder to the same surface, at least a foot and a half away from the swift.

2. Place the loop of the yarn around the arms of the swift, then loosen the screw under the arms and lift up to expand them like an umbrella. Lift until the skein is taut, then tighten the screw to secure.

### Winding Process
- Once you have everything set up, you're ready to start winding your yarn! You will slowly start to turn the handle on your yarn winder clockwise. You can use your other hand to gently guide the yarn to keep even more control on the tension.

- Once everything is in place, it's time to start cranking that handle! It helps to use your other hand to hold tension on the yarn when you are getting started. You should start to see a criss-cross pattern forming on your winder and the swift should be spinning freely. Keep winding until you reach the other end (which can be tucked somewhere on the outside of the cake to keep it secure). Slide your beautiful cake of yarn off the winder and enjoy!

### Alternatives If You Don't Have a Swift
Drape the yarn hank over the back of a sturdy chair. Make sure it's spread out evenly so it doesn't tangle as you wind.(no content)The old school method is to have a friend (or a willing family member) hold the yarn loop open while you wind. This works best if they gently rotate their hands as you pull the yarn.

- Knit Picks has an instructional video on their YouTube channel that walks you through how to use the Knit Picks Yarn Swift (available at youtube.com/watch?v=lnKbCGk7Ass).

- There is a Schacht swift demonstration and instructions on how to use a Knitpicks umbrella swift with a ball winder.

### What is an Umbrella Swift?
An umbrella swift is an ingenious device for holding skeins under tension so you can unravel them and easily wrap your yarn into balls. It works much like the inner workings of an umbrella, hence its name. A center pole clamps onto a table, and the pole holds several crisscrossed arms (usually between 5 and 8) that sit flush to the pole, like an umbrella. As you push up the pole from the bottom, the arms slowly extend outwards. The entire umbrella mechanism floats on the pole so it can spin freely.

### Key Reviews and Recommendations:
- An umbrella swift got its name because it opens similar to an umbrella. This contraption-looking swift is popular and can come in more expensive, but well-made handcrafted hardwoods or less expensive metal and plastic options (they can be found on Amazon for as low as $15.99).

- Today's umbrella swifts come in either solid wood or a combination of plastic and metal. The plastic and metal ones are less expensive (selling in the $49 range) and often more lightweight. However, they can lack the warmer, more aesthetically pleasing pleasure of wood. Among the simpler wood models, prices range from $75 for the simpler bare woods to $250 for beautiful handcrafted swifts.

- Using an Umbrella Swift and a Ball Winder Combo saves you an enormous amount of time.

Based on my search, I found information about umbrella opening and closing mechanisms, though I didn't find specific YouTube video results. Here's what I found about umbrella swift opening and closing mechanisms:

## Umbrella Opening and Closing Mechanisms

### How Automatic Opening Works
Inside the stem of the umbrella, there is a helical spring which stores potential energy when the umbrella is closed. This spring releases stored energy when you press a button or switch.(no content)Inside the umbrella shaft, there's a coiled spring. When the umbrella's closed, this spring gets pressed tight, storing "potential energy." When you press the button, the small piece holding the spring in place lets go, and the spring releases that stored energy, pushing the umbrella shaft up.

### How Automatic Closing Works
Automatic umbrellas can usually be closed with the same button or switch. When pressed, the closing mechanism is triggered and the internal mechanism releases the tension in the coil spring stored within the stem. This released energy causes the ribs to fold inward.(no content)Umbrellas are also usually equipped with a locking mechanism that ensures the canopy stays compact when fully folded. This ensures that the umbrella can be easily stored and used again when needed.

### Key Components
The umbrella mechanism is made up of several components that work together to make it easy to fold and unfold the umbrella. These components include the metal shaft, canopy, ribs, button, spring, stretcher, and other smaller parts.(no content)Some umbrellas feature an automatic open and close function, where a simple push of a button activates the spring mechanism to simultaneously release or collapse the stretcher and ribs.

### Usage Tips
One important thing to keep in mind when using an auto open and close umbrella is to avoid forcing it. If the umbrella does not open or close with ease, do not force it. This can cause damage to the umbrella and may even cause it to break. Instead, gently wiggle the umbrella or give it a little shake to loosen it up.

If you're looking for specific YouTube videos demonstrating these mechanisms, you may want to search directly on YouTube for visual demonstrations of umbrella mechanisms.

Here are the search results for your query about KnitPicks yarn swift ball winder tutorials:

## KnitPicks Yarn Swift & Ball Winder Tutorial Resources

### Official KnitPicks Resources

KnitPicks has a dedicated video page for "Winding Yarn with a Ball Winder and Swift" on their website at knitpicks.com/video/winding-using-ball-winder-and-swift.

### How to Use a Ball Winder

According to KnitPicks tutorials:

Yarn hanks need to be wound into cakes or balls before knitting or crocheting. A hank is a loop of yarn with two ends; if you knit directly from an opened hank, your yarn may become tangled. By winding a hank into a cake, you create a portable ball of yarn that is easy to work from and will not tangle.

**Setup Steps:**
- Use a Yarn Swift to hold hanks of yarn open and in place as you wind them into cakes using a Ball Winder. Secure swift and ball winder to table top or counter up to 1-1/2" thick with bottom clamp. Be sure there is enough clearance around the swift for the umbrella to fully open and spin freely.

**Winding Process:**
1. Untwist your yarn. It should come in a nicely twisted figure 8 hank, and when it is untwisted, it will look like a big loop of yarn. Drape the open hank over the closed swift and pull it lightly to hold it at the center of the ribs. Open the swift like an umbrella, pushing the runner up the center shaft until your loose yarn hank is held firmly around the swift.

2. Make sure your yarn is not twisted anywhere around the swift. Cut the ties around the hank. Now find the end of the yarn and pull, and the swift should spin freely. Thread yarn tail through the guide on your ball winder. Secure the thread by pressing the strand down into the notch at the top of the spindle. Turn the handle clockwise to wind your yarn into a cake around the spindle.

3. Pro tip: For best winding, position your ball winder so that the metal guide is pointing directly toward the swift and not at an angle.

**Tips to Avoid Tangles:**
- Don't turn the handle too quickly and try to keep a steady pace to avoid yarn tangles. Stop winding the yarn if a tangle develops and untangle any knots before proceeding. Keep turning the handle until the yarn swift is empty.

### Product Information

The KnitPicks Ball Winder can transform hanks or skeins into compact center-pull balls that sit nicely while you knit. A clamp secures the ball winder to the table while you wind skeins up to 100 grams or 3.5 ounces.(no content)The Yarn Swift is described as an essential tool for any knitter or crocheter that holds your hanks of yarn in place as you wind them into balls. Simply clamp the swift onto a table or countertop to start winding yarn neatly and easily.

### Additional Resources

- The Blue Elephants blog has a video tutorial specifically about the Knit Picks ball winder
- Stitch Clinic also offers video demonstrations of the winding process

results:
Based on my search, here's what I found about umbrella swift scissor mechanism arms, rivet construction, and how they expand:

## Scissor Mechanism Basics

Scissor linkages have a simple and effective geometry, consisting of bars connected via hinges that allow the mechanism to expand and contract smoothly. In particular, each scissor comprises a pair of bars connected to each other at an intermediate point by means of a pivotal connection that allows relative rotation of the two bars about an axis perpendicular to their plane. At their ends, the two bars are hinged to the bars of other scissors.

## Rivet Construction

The linkage consists of a number of stages, each stage consisting of two arms joined at their midpoints by a rivet that allows the arms to rotate against each other. Arms in adjacent stages are joined at their endpoints with joints that again allow for rotation.(no content)Panto scissor arms have the most distinctive feature of the mechanism. These consist of sturdy steel bars connected with rivet joints in an "X" shape. Due to the strength of these arms, the platform is lifted or lowered in the desired length.

## How Expansion Works

The crossed metal arms form an "X" figure, which is getting bigger or smaller like the blades of a pair of scissors. The point of the arms base where force is put in, the "X" becomes bigger and therefore the platform over the scissor arms is lifted. At the same time, the release of the force makes the arms get closer and, thus, the platform goes down.

## Umbrella Cell Expansion

Each cell consists of three pairs of arms joined as vertical scissor mechanisms around X-joints. The arms connect to rigid plates (top and bottom) through T-joints. The cell is deployed by pushing the top and bottom plates towards each other. This causes the arms to rotate and expand the lateral footprint of the cell.

## Key Properties

Deployable structures are flexible structures that can be transformed from a compact, stowed state to a predetermined, expanded configuration by means of actuation. Due to their ease of portability, lightness, and shape-shifting capability, deployable structures have found applications in many disciplines, including aerospace engineering, architecture, structural engineering, robotics, machinery, and mechatronics.(no content)The mechanism works on the same principle as an accordion or a folding ladder. These items being able to expand and collapse without any hitch, the pantograph mechanism also assures an exact vertical movement with no lateral play.

Based on the search results, I found information related to your query about YouTube links and yarn umbrella swifts:

## Search Results

### Yarn Umbrella Swift - Woodworking Discussion
A woodturner on the American Association of Woodturners forum was looking to make an umbrella swift for his wife who is a weaver. He searched for dimensions including length, thickness and width of slats, size of rotating hubs, height of central pole, etc., and wondered if anyone had made one and could share critical dimensions.

The discussion includes a reference to a YouTube video: `https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vNSEXRRxOzQ`

One commenter provided helpful dimensions for a yarn swift they purchased: "the slats...straight pieces that are linked together with string...are about 14" long, 9/16" wide, and 3/16" thick. Their edges are slightly rounded over. The only change I'd make to the design is to increase the depth of the wooden screw that clamps the swift on to the table."

### Sailor Swift Top Knitting Pattern
There's also a Pinterest pin for a "Sailor Swift Top" knitting pattern by Veronika Lindberg, which includes a video tutorial on YouTube at `https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dw7PArMh-ds`. The pattern is described as "a simple tank top with a slight racerback shape that gives it a contemporary look and a slight cool-girl vibe."

### Additional Context
The search also returned some general information about YouTube URL formats, explaining that "youtu.be" is a domain hack where the ".be" represents Belgium's country domain, used as a shorthand for YouTube's full URL format.

**üìã SUMMARY:** Comprehensive research on the Schacht Ultra Umbrella Swift, a premium yarn swift priced at $375-$424, focusing on ball bearing mechanism, folding design, premium features, and video demonstrations.

**‚úÖ RESULTS:**

## Schacht Ultra Umbrella Swift - Complete Research Report

### PRICING
- **Without Counter:** $375.00
- **With Counter:** $424.00
- **Availability:** Generally in stock, but may require 4-5 weeks for delivery as items are often drop-shipped from manufacturer

### HOW THE BALL BEARING MECHANISM WORKS

The Ultra Umbrella Swift features **ball bearings for exceptionally smooth turning**. The entire swift rotates freely on a ball bearing system mounted on the center post, allowing it to spin smoothly as yarn is wound off. This is a significant upgrade from traditional swifts that rely on simple post-and-sleeve friction systems.

**Key mechanical advantages:**
- Eliminates friction and resistance during rotation
- Allows for faster winding without jamming
- Reduces wear on the center post
- Enables consistent tension throughout the winding process
- Works equally well in both vertical and horizontal positions

### HOW THE ARMS FOLD/EXPAND

The Schacht Ultra has a **revolutionary push-down expansion mechanism** that differs from traditional umbrella swifts:

**Traditional swifts:** Arms slide up from the bottom and expand automatically
**Schacht Ultra:** Arms expand as you **push down on the top** of the swift

**How it works:**
1. Load the yarn skein onto the collapsed arms
2. Push down from the top (instead of lifting from bottom)
3. Arms expand outward to hold the skein taut
4. **Anti-flare design:** Arms will NOT automatically collapse when the skein is emptied
5. Holds skeins up to **93 inches in circumference**
6. When finished, collapses compactly for storage

**Folded dimensions:** 35.5‚Ä≥ √ó 7‚Ä≥ √ó 7‚Ä≥  
**Open dimensions:** 27‚Ä≥ √ó 36‚Ä≥ √ó 36‚Ä≥  
**Weight:** 5 lbs

### WHAT MAKES IT PREMIUM

**1. Superior Construction Materials:**
- **Solid steel pins** to keep slats stable (not plastic)
- **Tube-and-button connectors** for durable slat assembly
- **Stable slat pivots** with reinforced attachment points
- High-quality hardwood construction
- Redesigned base (July 2021) for streamlined aesthetics

**2. Advanced Engineering:**
- Ball bearing rotation system (most swifts use simple friction)
- Push-down expansion mechanism prevents accidental flaring
- Can be used **vertically OR horizontally** (rare feature)
- Built-in winding handle at the top

**3. Versatile Mounting System:**
- **Ingenious clamp** that accommodates tables of varying thickness
- Works on thick countertops and thin tabletops alike
- Secure mounting prevents wobbling during use

**4. Optional Revolution Counter:**
- Counts forwards AND backwards
- Makes it easy to determine exact skein yardage
- Professional feature for production work

**5. Handcrafted Quality:**
- Made by skilled craftspeople in Boulder, Colorado
- Modular replacement parts available (not disposable)
- Built to last decades with proper care

**6. Professional Capacity:**
- 93-inch circumference capacity (handles large skeins)
- Designed for both hobbyist and professional fiber artists

### VIDEO DEMONSTRATIONS

**Official Schacht Video:**
Schacht Spindle Company has an instructional video on their FAQ page:
- [How do I use the Ultra Umbrella Swift?](https://schachtspindle.com/blogs/faqs/how-do-i-use-the-ultra-umbrella-swift)

**Note:** While the search didn't return direct YouTube links, Schacht's official website and several retailers mention embedded video demonstrations. The official Schacht FAQ page specifically states "Watch our video!" for usage instructions.

**Alternative Tutorial Resources:**
- Purl Soho has general umbrella swift tutorials showing winding techniques
- Several retailers (Weft Blown, Woolery) reference demonstration videos on their product pages

### PRODUCT PAGES WITH MULTIPLE IMAGES

**Official Manufacturer:**
- [Schacht Spindle Company - Ultra Umbrella Swift](https://schachtspindle.com/products/ultra-umbrella-swift) - Official product page with specifications and images

**Parts Diagram:**
- [Ultra Umbrella Swift Parts Diagram](https://schachtspindle.com/blogs/product-diagrams/ultra-umbrella-swift-parts) - Technical parts breakdown

**Authorized Retailers with Images:**
- [Paradise Fibers - $357-$424](https://paradisefibers.com/products/schacht-ultra-umbrella-swift) - Multiple product photos
- [The Woolery](https://woolery.com/schacht-ultra-umbrella-swift.html) - Detailed images and specifications
- [Eugene Textile Center](https://www.eugenetextilecenter.com/home/etc/page_253_64/ultra_umbrella_swift.html)
- [Yarn Barn Kansas - $357](https://www.yarnbarn-ks.com/Schacht-Ultra-Umbrella-Swift/productinfo/WA-WW-SWS-/) - 20% discount currently available
- [LoftyFiber](https://loftyfiber.com/products/schacht-ultra-umbrella-swift)

### COMPETITIVE CONTEXT

The $375-$424 price point makes this one of the most expensive umbrella swifts on the market:
- Basic plastic/metal swifts: $15-$50
- Mid-range wood swifts: $75-$150
- Premium handcrafted swifts: $200-$250
- **Schacht Ultra: $375-$424** (top tier)

The premium is justified by ball bearings, steel construction, push-down mechanism, and American craftsmanship.
